maml:description.maml:para: Adds an endpoint to a Traffic Manager Profile.
Adds an endpoint to a Traffic Manager Profile. This cmdlet does not access Microsoft Azure, so its output should be piped into Set-AzureTrafficManagerEndpoint.
The domain name of the endpoint to add.
The name of the Traffic Manager profile to add the endpoint.
Specifies the status of the monitoring endpoint. If set to Enabled, the endpoint is considered by the load balancing method and is monitored. Possible values are: -- Enabled -- Disabled
The Traffic Manager profile object to add the endpoint.

The type of endpoint.
If there is more than one AzureWebsite endpoint, they must be in different datacenters. This limitation doesn't apply to cloud services.
Possible values are: - CloudService - AzureWebsite - Any

The location of the endpoint to add. This must be one of the Azure locations. This is necessary for endpoints of type "Any" in profiles with a load balancing method "Performance" A list of possible values can be found under Name by calling List Locations: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/gg441293.aspx

The weight of the endpoint to add.
This parameter is only used in RoundRobin policies. The valid range for this value is [1,1000].
The domain name of the endpoint to add.

The location of the endpoint to add. This must be one of the Azure locations. This is necessary for endpoints of type "Any" in profiles with a load balancing method "Performance" A list of possible values can be found under Name by calling List Locations: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/gg441293.aspx
The name of the Traffic Manager profile to add the endpoint.
Specifies the status of the monitoring endpoint. If set to Enabled, the endpoint is considered by the load balancing method and is monitored. Possible values are: -- Enabled -- Disabled
The Traffic Manager profile object to add the endpoint.

The type of endpoint.
If there is more than one AzureWebsite endpoint, they must be in different datacenters. This limitation doesn't apply to cloud services.
Possible values are: - CloudService - AzureWebsite - Any

The weight of the endpoint to add.
This parameter is only used in RoundRobin policies. The valid range for this value is [1,1000].
A Traffic Manager profile object, which contains information about the profile being updated.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Add-AzureTrafficManagerEndpoint -DomainName myapp2.cloudapp.net -Name myProfile -TrafficManagerProfile myTrafficManagerProfile -Type CloudService -Status Enabled
Traffic Manager profile object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Adds an endpoint to a Traffic Manager profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-AzureTrafficManagerProfile myProfile | Add-AzureTrafficManagerEndpoint -DomainName myapp2.cloudapp.net -Name myProfile -TrafficManagerProfile myTrafficManagerProfile -Type CloudService -Status Enabled | Set-AzureTrafficManagerProfile
Traffic Manager profile object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Adds an endpoint to a Traffic Manager profile and save the operation.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Add-AzureTrafficManagerEndpoint -DomainName myapp2.cloudapp.net -Name myTrafficManagerName -TrafficManagerProfile myTrafficManagerProfile -Type CloudService -Status Enabled -Weight 2 -Location myLocation
Traffic Manager profile object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Adds an endpoint to a Traffic Manager profile using optional parameters.

maml:description.maml:para: Disables a Traffic Manager Profile.
Disables a Traffic Manager profile. Returns $true if -PassThru is passed.
The name of the Traffic Manager profile to disable.
Shows you the results of the cmdlet.
The name of the Traffic Manager profile to disable.
Shows you the results of the cmdlet.
Returns true if the operation was successful if -PassThru was set; false otherwise.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Disable-AzureTrafficManagerProfile myProfile -PassThru
Returns true if the operation was successful if -PassThru was set; false otherwise.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Disables a Traffic Manager profile using optional parameters.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Disable-AzureTrafficManagerProfile myProfile
Returns true if the operation was successful if -PassThru was set; false otherwise.

maml:description.maml:para: Enables a Traffic Manager profile.
Enables a Traffic Manager profile. Returns $true if -PassThru is passed.
The name of the Traffic Manager profile to enable.
Shows you the results of the cmdlet.
The name of the Traffic Manager profile to enable.
Shows you the results of the cmdlet.
Returns true if the operation was successful if -PassThru was set; false otherwise.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Enable-AzureTrafficManagerProfile myProfile
Returns true if the operation was successful if -PassThru was set; false otherwise.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Enable-AzureTrafficManagerProfile myProfile -PassThru
Returns true if the operation was successful if -PassThru was set; false otherwise.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Enables a Traffic Manager profile using optional parameters.

maml:description.maml:para: Obtains the details of a Traffic Manager profile.
Obtains the details of a Traffic Manager profile. If no "-Name" is passed, a list of Traffic Manager profiles in the current subscription is returned.
The name of the Traffic Manager profile to get.
The name of the Traffic Manager profile to get.
The Traffic Manager profile object(s).

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-AzureTrafficManagerProfile
A list of Traffic Manager profile for each profile in the subscription.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-AzureTrafficManagerProfile -Name myProfile
Traffic Manager profile object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets a Traffic Manager profile using optional parameters.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-AzureTrafficManagerProfile myProfile | Add-AzureTrafficManagerEndpoint -DomainName myapp2.cloudapp.net -Name myProfile -TrafficManagerProfile myTrafficManagerProfile -Type CloudService -Status Enabled | Set-AzureTrafficManagerProfile
Traffic Manager profile object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Adds an endpoint to a Traffic Manager profile and save the operation.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new Azure Traffic Manager profile.
Creates a new Azure Traffic Manager profile.
The domain name of the Traffic Manager profile. This must be a subdomain of trafficmanager.net
Specifies the load balancing method to use to distribute connection. Possible values are: Performance Failover RoundRobin
Specifies the port used to monitor endpoint health. Accepted values are integer values greater than 0 and less or equal to 65,535.
Specifies the protocol to use to monitor endpoint health. Possible values are: HTTP HTTPS

Specifies the path relative to the endpoint domain name to probe for health state. Restrictions are: The path must be from 1 through 1000 characters. It must start with a forward slash /. It must contain no XML element <>. It must contain no double slashes //. It must contain no invalid HTML escape characters. For example, %XY.
The name of the Traffic Manager profile to create.
Specifies the DNS Time-to-Live (TTL) that informs the Local DNS resolvers how long to cache DNS entries. The value is an integer from 30 through 999,999
The domain name of the Traffic Manager profile. This must be a subdomain of trafficmanager.net
Specifies the load balancing method to use to distribute connection. Possible values are: Performance Failover RoundRobin
Specifies the port used to monitor endpoint health. Accepted values are integer values greater than 0 and less or equal to 65,535.
Specifies the protocol to use to monitor endpoint health. Possible values are: HTTP HTTPS

Specifies the path relative to the endpoint domain name to probe for health state. Restrictions are: The path must be from 1 through 1000 characters. It must start with a forward slash /. It must contain no XML element <>. It must contain no double slashes //. It must contain no invalid HTML escape characters. For example, %XY.
The name of the Traffic Manager profile to create.
Specifies the DNS Time-to-Live (TTL) that informs the Local DNS resolvers how long to cache DNS entries. The value is an integer from 30 through 999,999
The Traffic Manager profile object.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
New-AzureTrafficManagerProfile -Name myProfile -DomainName my.profile.trafficmanager.net -LoadBalancingMethod RoundRobin -TTL 30 -MonitorProtocol HTTP -MonitorPort 80 -MonitorRelativePath /
Traffic Manager profile object.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes an endpoint from a Traffic Manager profile.
Removes an endpoint from a Traffic Manager profile. This cmdlet does not access Microsoft Azure, so its output should be piped into Set-AzureTrafficManagerEndpoint.
The domain name of the endpoint to add.
The name of the Traffic Manager profile to add the endpoint.
The Traffic Manager profile object to remove the endpoint.
Switch parameter to avoid confirming endpoint deletion.
The domain name of the endpoint to add.
Switch parameter to avoid confirming endpoint deletion.
The name of the Traffic Manager profile to add the endpoint.
The Traffic Manager profile object to remove the endpoint.
A Traffic Manager profile object, which contains information about the profile being removed.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Remove-AzureTrafficManagerEndpoint -DomainName myapp2.cloudapp.net -Name myProfile -TrafficManagerProfile myTrafficManagerProfile
Traffic Manager profile object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Removes an endpoint from a Traffic Manager profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Remove-AzureTrafficManagerEndpoint -DomainName myapp2.cloudapp.net -Name myProfile -TrafficManagerProfile myTrafficManagerProfile -Force
Traffic Manager profile object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Removes an endpoint from a Traffic Manager profile using optional parameters.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-AzureTrafficManagerProfile myProfile | Remove-AzureTrafficManagerEndpoint -DomainName myapp2.cloudapp.net -Name myProfile -TrafficManagerProfile myTrafficManagerProfile | Set-AzureTrafficManagerProfile
Traffic Manager profile object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Removes an endpoint from a Traffic Manager profile and save the operation.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a Traffic Manager Profile from the current subscription.
Remove a Traffic Manager profile.
Name of the Traffic Manager profile to delete.
Switch parameter to avoid confirming profile deletion.
Shows you the results of the cmdlet.
Switch parameter to avoid confirming profile deletion.
Name of the Traffic Manager profile to delete.
Shows you the results of the cmdlet.
Returns true if the operation was successful if -PassThru was set; false otherwise.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Remove-AzureTrafficManagerProfile -Name myProfile
Returns true if the operation was successful if -PassThru was set; false otherwise.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Remove-AzureTrafficManagerProfile -Name myProfile -Force -PassThru
Returns true if the operation was successful if -PassThru was set; false otherwise.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Removes a Traffic Manager profile using optional parameters.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates the properties of an endpoint from a Traffic Manager profile.

Updates the properties of an endpoint from a Traffic Manager profile. If the endpoint does not exist in the current profile, it will create it. This cmdlet does not access Microsoft Azure, so its output should be piped into Set-AzureTrafficManagerEndpoint.
The domain name of the endpoint to add.
The name of the Traffic Manager profile to add the endpoint.
The Traffic Manager profile object to set the endpoint.

The location of the endpoint. This must be one of the Azure locations. This is necessary for endpoints of type "Any" in profiles with a load balancing method "Performance" A list of possible values can be found under Name by calling List Locations: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/gg441293.aspx
Specifies the status of the monitoring endpoint. If set to Enabled, the endpoint is considered by the load balancing method and is monitored. Possible values are: -- Enabled -- Disabled

The type of endpoint.
If there is more than one AzureWebsite endpoint, they must be in different datacenters. This limitation doesn't apply to cloud services.
Possible values are: - CloudService - AzureWebsite - Any

The weight of the endpoint .
This parameter is only used in RoundRobin policies. The valid range for this value is [1,1000].
The domain name of the endpoint to add.

The location of the endpoint. This must be one of the Azure locations. This is necessary for endpoints of type "Any" in profiles with a load balancing method "Performance" A list of possible values can be found under Name by calling List Locations: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/gg441293.aspx
The name of the Traffic Manager profile to add the endpoint.
Specifies the status of the monitoring endpoint. If set to Enabled, the endpoint is considered by the load balancing method and is monitored. Possible values are: -- Enabled -- Disabled
The Traffic Manager profile object to set the endpoint.

The type of endpoint.
If there is more than one AzureWebsite endpoint, they must be in different datacenters. This limitation doesn't apply to cloud services.
Possible values are: - CloudService - AzureWebsite - Any

The weight of the endpoint .
This parameter is only used in RoundRobin policies. The valid range for this value is [1,1000].
A Traffic Manager profile object, which contains information about the profile being updated.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Add-AzureTrafficManagerEndpoint -DomainName myapp2.cloudapp.net -Name myTrafficManagerName -TrafficManagerProfile myTrafficManagerProfile -Type CloudService -Weight 2 -Location myLocation -Status Enabled
Traffic Manager profile object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Updates an endpoint from a Traffic Manager profile using optional parameters.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Get-AzureTrafficManagerProfile myProfile | Set-AzureTrafficManagerEndpoint -DomainName myapp2.cloudapp.net -Name myProfile -TrafficManagerProfile myTrafficManagerProfile -Type CloudService | Set-AzureTrafficManagerProfile
Traffic Manager profile object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Updates an endpoint from a Traffic Manager profile and save the operation.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Set-AzureTrafficManagerEndpoint -DomainName myapp2.cloudapp.net -Name myProfile -TrafficManagerProfile myTrafficManagerProfile -Type CloudService
Traffic Manager profile object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Updates an endpoint from a Traffic Manager profile.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates the properties of a Traffic Manager profile.
Updates the properties of a Traffic Manager profile.
The name of the Traffic Manager profile to update.
The Traffic Manager profile object to set the profile.
Specifies the load balancing method to use to distribute connection. Possible values are: Performance Failover RoundRobin
Specifies the port used to monitor endpoint health. Accepted values are integer values greater than 0 and less or equal to 65,535.
Specifies the protocol to use to monitor endpoint health. Possible values are: HTTP HTTPS

Specifies the path relative to the endpoint domain name to probe for health state. Restrictions are: The path must be from 1 through 1000 characters. It must start with a forward slash /. It must contain no XML element <>. It must contain no double slashes //. It must contain no invalid HTML escape characters. For example, %XY.
The Time-To-Live to assign to this Traffic Manager profile.
Specifies the load balancing method to use to distribute connection. Possible values are: Performance Failover RoundRobin
Specifies the port used to monitor endpoint health. Accepted values are integer values greater than 0 and less or equal to 65,535.
Specifies the protocol to use to monitor endpoint health. Possible values are: HTTP HTTPS

Specifies the path relative to the endpoint domain name to probe for health state. Restrictions are: The path must be from 1 through 1000 characters. It must start with a forward slash /. It must contain no XML element <>. It must contain no double slashes //. It must contain no invalid HTML escape characters. For example, %XY.
The name of the Traffic Manager profile to update.
The Traffic Manager profile object to set the profile.
The Time-To-Live to assign to this Traffic Manager profile.
The Traffic Manager profile object.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Set-AzureTrafficManagerProfile -Name myProfile -TrafficManagerProfile myTrafficManagerProfile -TTL 60
Traffic Manager profile object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Set the TTL for a Traffic Manager profile.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Set-AzureTrafficManagerProfile -Name myProfile -TrafficManagerProfile myTrafficManagerProfile -LoadBalancingMethod RoundRobin -TTL 30 -MonitorProtocol HTTP -MonitorPort 80 -MonitorRelativePath /
Traffic Manager profile object.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Set the LoadBalancingMethod, TTL, MonitorProtocol, MonitorPort and MonitorRelativePath for a Traffic Manager profile.

maml:description.maml:para: Tests the availability of a domain name as a Traffic Manager profile.
Tests the availability of a domain name as a Traffic Manager profile.
The domain name to test. You must include .trafficmanager.net
The domain name to test. You must include .trafficmanager.net
Returns true if the operation was successful if -PassThru was set; false otherwise.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code:
Test-AzureTrafficManagerDomainName -DomainName myapp.trafficmanager.net
Returns true if the domain name is available; false otherwise.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Test if a Traffic Manager domain name is available to be used.
